review_blob: 12 oz. bottle:  Pours a cloudy lighter brown with a sustaining white head.  Aromas are plentiful with dark fruit sweetness (plums, raisons), tartness as well.  Flavor was mostly the tart fruit, some spice bite, and caramel and brown sugar touches.

12 oz. bottle:  Pours a lightly hazy golden color with a diminishing white head.  Aromas are of light hops, no real apricot notes.  Flavor is the same with mellow hops, and maybe some light apricot sweetness.

Bottle, 750mL:  Pours a well carbonated body, brown in color, with a large sustaining tan rocky head.  Aromas are fruity and tart, with a slighty mustiness in the background.  Flavor was fruity sweet, with some caramel and sugars.  Lots of tickling mouthfeel.

Bottle, bomber:  Pours an opaque oily black, very little carbonation within the body, has a large brown head which is mostly lasting.  Aromas are milk chocolate, roast/toast, coffee, and the oak barrell is definately present.  Flavor is mostly sweet milk chocolate milk, soem bitterness and dryness at the finish.  Velvety mouthfeel.

Botlle, 750mL:  Pours a lighter golden body which is well carbonated, with a white larger bubbled head with diminishes rather quickly.  Aromas are sweet first and foremost with citrus and melon, brett foreshadowing, mild herb spice, and of course yeast.  Flavor does not dissapoint fruit that blends into a bretty sourness, finishes bready.  Tickling mouthfeel.

22 o z bottle:  Pours a completely tranparent amber/orange body with a large foamy white head that is fully lasting to the last sip.  Aromas are dominated by the hops, slightly fruity and slightly spicy.  Flavor is surprising at first (like the first sip of a devil dancer) with just massive hop bitterness, bitingly at that, I wish I couldve seen my face!  Flavor mellows, though only slightly, as your palate warms up to the beer, and the sweeter notes, oranges, pinapple present themselves.  Definately underbalanced, it is afterall a showcase of hop glory.

12 oz Bottle:  Pours a cloudy orange color with a smallish white somewhat lasting head.  Aromas were big and bold, lots of hops, fruit and pine, some stank malt as well.  Flavor is absolutely amazing, starts off quite bitter and grapefruity, then mellows slightly into a citrusy (orange mostly) weak bitterness, its final transformation leaves the taste of sweet peaches in your mouth.  Finishes so smooth and sweat, great full mouthfeel.

Bottle:  Pours a could dark orange with a large sustaining head, very rocky.  Aromas are loaded with outdoors, woods, leaves, earth, lots of fruit as well, oranges and other citrus.  Flavor is lightly sour fruits, quite spicy, sweet caramel.

12 oz. bottle:  Pours a pale cloudy golden color with a rapidly diminishing white head.  Aromas of wheat, lemons, and light spice.  Flavor is mostly wheat and sweet lemons, no tartness really.  Finishes clean.

Bomber, batch 63:  Pours a medium golden color with a large white rocky head which grows from a well carbonated body which wont sit still.  Aomras were peppery spices, some sweet malts, and yeast.  Flavor was awefully watered down weakening the light spiciness even more.  Finishes light and basically clean.

Bomber:  Pours a darker red/bown combination with a small rapidly diminshing head.  Aromas are sweet and spicy.  Flavor is fruity at first, with some slight spice, and turns bitter as the hops present themselves more and more as the beer warms and gets neared the end of the bottle.  Finishes warmingly strong.

Bomber:  Pours a burnt orange color with a large bubbling white head.  Upon pouring this beer sweet hop aromas fill your nose, citrus and pine galore!  Flavor is sweet hops, with perfect bitterness and a nice malt balance.
Bottle:  Pours a light golden color with a well carbonated body and a white fully diminishing head.  Aromas are of weak yeast and lemons.  Flavor is watered down and weak.

12 oz. bottle:  Pours an opaque black with a tall hilly brown head.  Aromas were rather mellow, no outstanding chocolate scents, mostly roasty notes on top of a solid malt backbone.  Flavor seems to showcase the dark chocolate a bitter more with a dry bitter sweetness, still lots of roast.  Heavy and coating mouthfeel, finishes slightly dry and sweet.

22 oz. Bottle:  Pours an amberish dark brown color with a white head.  Aromas are very dark sweet fruits, caramel, oak and strong presense of bourbon alcohol.  Flavor was bitingly sweet, overly so in fact, with lots of sugary treats like caramel, toffee, vanilla.  Finishes with a little less of an alcohol bite, but isnt all that warming.
UPDATED: AUG 31, 2005

12 oz. can:  What is this, a can in the 90th percentile, can it be true?  Wasnt sure what to think at first, but upon opening this beer I knew I was in for a treat.  Pours a nice golden color with a nmedium sized frothy white head.  Aromas of big hops hit your nose instantly, so fruity so piney.  Flavor is mostly the same, lots of hops.  Very nice drying mouthfeel, finishes with the fruity sweetness of the hops.  Best can beer there is.

12 oz. bottle:  Pours a hazy golden/light orange with a lively white head, mostly lasting.  Aromas of alcohol, various fruits (very fruity), some light spice tickle.  Flavor was sweet mixed with bourbon alcohol, woody (must be the oak barrell) with some light fruit as well.

12 oz. Bottle:  Pours a transparent lighter bron color with a small white head.  Aromas of sweet caramel malt.  Flavor was less sweet and more sour, caramel was non-existent and replaced by sour hops.  Clean finishing.

12 oz. bottle, from 1998:  Think that this one may have been in the bottle a bit too long.  Found it a smaller beer store that doesnt appear to pay much attention.  Poured a darker orange/brown with a receding white head.  Aromas were very sweet darkerk fruits and caramel.  Flavor was very light and clean, not a whole lot there, watered down caramel.

Bottle, bomber:  Pours a nice deep copper color with a large slightly rocky white head that is mostly sustaining.  Decent Lacing.  Aromas of huge hops, floral and fruity, just what you would expect from a big IPA.  Flavor was sweet fruit hops at first, but quickly became very bitter on top of the sweetness.  Drying mouthfeel.
12 oz. Bottle:  Transparent brown with a light tan head which is mostly diminishing.  Aromas of faint malt and some spice.  Flavor is surprisingly nutty and slightly hoppy.

Bottle:  Cloudy golden with a decent amount of sediment floating around in the bottle, very lively, poured a large white head that diminished quickly.  Aromas of sweet citrus, malt, and yeast.  Flavor was very smooth sweet oranges, bananas.  Medium thickness, somewhat coating mouthfeel.
Bottle:  Transparent brown color with a rapidly diminishing white head.  Aromas are fruity sweet with a maltier backbone.  Flavor is bitingly sweet with a sour finish.

On tap at G.I. Clybourn:  Dark brown with a tan lasting one-fingered head.  Had to let this warm up a bit.  Huge nose of dark sweetness, maple syrup, raisens, pruns, brown sugar, you know this is going to have some bite to it.  Flavor is very warming from the alcohol, but it doesnt appear much, its well hidden behind the sweeter toffee, nuttiness, and fruits.  Heavy, coating mouthfeel.

On tap at G.I. Clybourn:  Brown/orange with a smallish off white head.  Fruity and bready aromas.  Flavor is much more spicy and tart than the nose leads on, finishes more toned down and smooth with breads and hops.

Bottle:  Dark orange in color with a large pillowy white head which lasts forever, leaves some nice lacing.  Nose of white sugars and alcohol.  Not much flavor to this one, mostly alcohol mixed with some bland hops.

Bomber:  Pours orange/amber with large sustaing rocky head.  Lots of sediment in this one boys and girls.  Aromas are all sorts of Belgian, lots of raisens and bananas, smooth yeast and malts.  Flavor is sweet and powerful, burnt caramel and toffee, sugars, warming alcohol.

12 oz. Bottle:  Unremarkable golden color with white head which doesnst last long.  Nose is mostly adjunct on top of a big malt base.  Flavor was pils-esque as it should be, malt goodness, finishes with grass and hay.
Bomber:  Light and watery all around, weakened nose of chocolate and milkier chocolate, bits of smoke linger as well.  Flavor is very weak watered down coffee, lacks body.

Bomber:  Beautiful looking brown/amber with a lasting somewhat rocky head.  Aromas of sweet malts caramel, toffee with hints of raisens and other dark fruits.  Flavor is yeast and malt back boned with the sweeter flavors up front.  Heavy mouthfeel, finishes with candy notes and alcohol.
beer_name: Dark Horse 3 Guy Off the Scale Old Ale

review_blob: Bomber:  Dark in appearance, tan head, mostly lasting.  Aromas of Dark malts, mostly coffee, hints of chocolate.  Slightly watery in flavor with chocolate and the slightest of hops.  Finsihes slightly bitter chocolate and water.

03 Bomber:  Looks good, pitch black, nice tan head.  Has the stout nose for sure, lots of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is strong coffee, with darker bitter chocolate, some alcohol near finish.  Pleasantly surprised.

Bomber, Batch 9:  Very nutty, woodsy, too much alcohol in the nose.  Flavor is fruit spice with a powerful alcohol bite at first, but it does mellow to showcase some very nice yeast spice.  Thick and velvety mouthfeel.
12 oz:  Was expecting more.  Nose of raisens and underdone sweetness.  Flavor was too watery and mellowed this beer out quite a bit, caramel malt and watery sourness.

Bomber:  Three Floyds needs to get some new caps, this violet and lime combo is a little fruity.  Good looking beer, large head, lasting.  Sweet citrus nose.  Flavor was fruit and very hoppy, noticably hoppy at that.  Finishes clean for the most part, some lasting fruity bitterness.
Bomber:  Typical aromas, though lighter than most hop-heavy beers.  Flavor followed suit with bitter hops, only toned down.  Dry finishing with a lighter mouthfeel.

Bomber, batch 16:  Sugary and sweet aromas with some spiciness there as well.  Flavor was that of big oudoors, hay fields, sweet citrus abounds.  Smooth and full mouthfeel, finishes with strong citrus.
Floral dank hops in the nose, very fruit and sweet smelling as well.  Flavor had strong hop kick and was quite dry.  Decent carbonation created a nice lively mouthfeel.  Could use more balance.
Spicy all the way around, from its peppery nose to its biting toungue tickling flavor.  Musty dry finish.  Good looks as well.

On draft:  Poured a deep golden color, white a slowly diminishing white head.  Aromas were weak and waterd down malt and adjunct.  Flavor was also light, some malt and bland hops.  Finishes clean with very little flavor.

Draft at The Office in Morristown, NJ:  Poured a transparent golden/amber with a diminishing white head.  Aromas are mostly watery hops and some malt in the background.  Flavor was uninteresting hops and caramel.  Light and watery mouthfeel.

Draft at The Office in Morristown, NJ:  Poured a cloudy golden with a lasting white head, left nice lacing.  Aromas were yeast and bananas.  Flavor was bubblegum and bananas, a little to sweet, and smooth belgian yeast.  A medium heavy mouthfeel.

Draft at The Office in Morristown, NJ:  Poured a amber/copper color with a diminishing off white head.  Aromas were piney hops and some caramel notes.  Flavor was generally roasted malt and caramel, decent amount of hops as well.

Bottle, 750 mL, 2005 vintage:  I was told the year to have was 02 or 04, but this 05 didnt disappoint in the least.  Poured a cloudy yellow/orange, plenty of sediment in this one, with a fully lasting near white head.  Aroma had a lot going on, at first smelling straight from the bottle I got a lot of fruit sweetness with ammonia.  Upon pouring the sweet fruit aromas grew and became slightly sour, cider notes, and just a dry overall feeling.  Flavor was sour dark melon and citrus, a little syrupy near finish, also had a nice spiciness to balance out the sweetness I thought.  Very lively mouthfeel, tickling helps with the sweetness.

12 oz. bottle:  Cloudy orange in color with a somewhat lasting white pillowy head.  Nose was light for the style I thought, with oranges and yeast, slight sourness as well.  Flavor was also light I thought, I missed the heavy yeast and sweetness, seemed just a little over watered.  Finishes with a citrus sour kick.

Bottle, 22 oz.:  Pours an darker orange/amber color with a white head which diminishes slowly.  Aromas were sweeter malts and light piney hops.  Flavor was spicier fruit combinations ending with some hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel was overall faily light.

12 oz bottle:  A transparent light yellow, with a quickly diminishing white head.  Strong corn aroma and other adjunct common to crappy beer.  Flavor was skunky and sour and entirely forgettable, pil-esque if I had to mention anything.  Watery think mouthfeel, finishes clean.

On tap at brewery:  Light transparent orange with a big near white head, nice lacing.  Aromas were faint and hard to detect IMHO, seriously got nothing in the nose, faint sugars is about it.  Flavor was sweet sugars/honey like, missed out on the bitterness and detected a musty sourness instead that wasnt all that tasty.  Finishes with a watery sourness.

On tap at brewery:  Ruby/copper in color with a mostly sustaining tan head.  aromas are floral herb gardens, spice, and salt/soy notes.  Flavor is the floral heather mixed with deadened weak hops, also had some salt hints which fade as the beer drains.  Finishes with all water and finishes quickly.
